page.title: 17FARMING IN L.STAUGHTON
page.content: The soil type in this area is predominantly chalky boulder clay, with pockets of silts and gravel in some of the lower lying areas. The clay is impervious,and in most cases the fields need a system of underground drains with gravel placed over them to allow the rain to percolate through the ground. This clay is ideally suited to the growing of{winter cereals,}and indeed winter wheat with some barley is by far the most widespread crops grown. Yields would be above the national average and a good crop of winter wheat could be expected to yield 7.5tonnes/hectare,currently valued at around 120pounds/ tonne,with barley worth slightly less.
